div.head: Summary
div.p: Praising the Lady Who Rules Disease, or, as it is alternatively titled, Eight Verses Praising the Glorious Goddess Mahākālī, is a short praise to the goddess Mahākālī in which she is portrayed as both a cause of human illness and a source of protection from it. The text is included in the Compendium of Dhāraṇīs section of the Degé Kangyur as well as in the Tantra section of the Degé Tengyur, and it was composed by the brahmin Vararuci.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: This text was translated by Catherine Dalton and edited by the 84000 editorial team.
The translation was completed under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha.

Praising the Lady Who Rules Disease, or, as it is alternatively titled, Eight Verses Praising the Glorious Goddess Mahākālī, is a short praise to the wrathful goddess Mahākālī in which she is identified as the best source of protection from human illness. The text was composed by the Brahmin Vararuci, who describes Mahākālī as black, naked, terrifying, eating human flesh, and frequenting cremation grounds. She is described as draped in a fresh hide, holding a bell, a skull, a sword, a spear, and a lion, with a snake spreading its hood behind her. In this short work, Vararuci depicts Mahākālī as so large that she tramples the earth, with the sun resting at the level of her navel, and marvels that gods such as Indra and Yama are compelled to bow trembling at her feet.

The praise includes a striking line in which Vararuci states that Mahākālī is “present as half of Mahādeva’s body,” a reference to Śiva’s form as Ardhanārīśvara—the “Lord Who Is Half Female.” The female “half” of Śiva in this form is generally identified as his consort Pārvatī, and in the very next line of the praise Vararuci uses one of Pārvatī’s most common epithets, Gaurī, identifying Mahākālī with her as well as with the goddess Durgā. These passages highlight the connection and interplay between Buddhism and both Śaiva and Śākta traditions. This relationship has been studied by a number of scholars, most prominently Ronald Davidson (2002) and Alexis Sanderson (2009).

This praise does not appear to survive in Sanskrit or to have been translated into Chinese. The text is included in the Compendium of Dhāraṇīs (gzungs ’dus) section of the Degé Kangyur and other Tshalpa-lineage Kangyurs that include a separate dhāraṇī section, Praising the Lady Who Rules Disease is one of only fifteen texts in the Compendium of Dhāraṇīs section of the Degé Kangyur (and the other Kangyurs that include such a section) that, unlike the other 235 works in the Compendium, does not also appear in duplicate in other sections of the Kangyur. and in the Tantra sections of Tshalpa-lineage Kangyurs that lack such a section. It is not found in any Kangyurs belonging to the Thempangma grouping, such as the Stok Palace Kangyur, nor do we find it in the Dunhuang collections. Since this text is recognized as having had a human author, the brahmin Vararuci, it is also included in all four recensions of the Tengyur. It seems likely that the work’s inclusion in some Kangyurs, despite clearly being an authored text, may be related to its being part of the Compendium of Dhāraṇīs, which seems to have been compiled on the basis of an earlier collection or collections of dhāraṇīs and associated ritual texts. Hidas notes a remark by Orosz that the Degé Kangyur catalog (dkar chag) identifies the source of the Compendium of Dhāraṇīs as the extracanonical collection edited by Tāranātha (Hidas 2021, p. 7, n. 56). These collections, known in Sanskrit as dhāraṇī­saṃgrahas, appear in South Asia and Tibet—including at Dunhuang and as extracanonical Tibetan dhāraṇī collections—and often include praises as well as dhāraṇīs and dhāraṇī-sūtras. See J. Dalton 2016 and J. Dalton and van Schaik 2006 on the dhāraṇī­saṃgraha collections preserved at Dunhuang, which contain praises and prayers as well as dhāraṇīs. See Hidas 2021 for the catalogs of eighteen dhāraṇī­saṃgraha collections surviving in Sanskrit, many of which also contain praises. As mentioned above, the present work has been preserved under two titles: the recension included in the Kangyurs is titled Praising the Lady Who Rules Disease, while that in the Tengyurs is titled Eight Verses Praising the Glorious Goddess Mahākālī. While these reflect the titles given at the incipit (and thus also in the catalogs) of the Kangyur and Tengyur recensions, the author’s colophons of both recensions show how it may have come to be known under these two different titles. The author’s colophon of the Tengyur recension reprises the title as “Eight Verses Praising the Glorious Goddess Mahākālī, the Lady Who Rules All Disease,” while the author’s colophon of the Kangyur recension gives it as: “Eight Verses Praising Mahākālī, the Lady who Rules all Diseases.”

Not much is known about the work’s author, the brahmin Vararuci, but in addition to this praise to Mahākālī, a series of works related to Mahākāla included in the Tengyur—two sādhanas, an empowerment rite, and a praise—are also attributed to him. The four Mahākāla-related works attributed to Vararuci are two Mahākāla-sādhanas (Toh 1761 and Toh 3386) , the Mahākālābhiṣeka-vidhi (Toh 1763) , and a Mahākāla-stotra (Toh 1774). One Vararuci (or, more probably several Vararucis) is also the author of a number of scientific and astrological texts composed in Sanskrit, but without further evidence it seems unlikely that those texts are authored by the same Vararuci as these several Buddhist works related to Mahākāla and Mahākālī that survive in translation in the Tibetan Kangyurs.

Neither the Kangyur nor the Tengyur recension of this praise includes a translator’s colophon, so we do not know who translated it, but the work is listed in the imperial Denkarma catalog (under the title found in its Kangyur recensions), so we know that it was translated prior to the collapse of the Tibetan empire in 843 ce. At the very end of the praise, the author uses exactly the same series of epithets for Mahākālī—“Yama’s Queen, Mother of Māra, Sovereign Goddess of the Desire Realm”—found in Mahākālī’s Dhāraṇī (Toh 670/1087), a text in the Kangyur also listed in both the Denkarma and Phangthangma imperial catalogs, so it is likely that Vararuci knew and was referencing that work.

This English translation was completed on the basis of both the Degé Kangyur and Tengyur recensions (Toh 1090The present text, and all those contained in this same volume (gzungs ’dus, wa), are listed as being located in volume 100 of the Degé Kangyur by the Buddhist Digital Resource Center (BDRC). However, several other Kangyur databases—including the eKangyur that supplies the digital input version displayed by the 84000 Reading Room—list this work as being located in volume 102. This discrepancy is partly due to the fact that the two volumes of the gzungs ’dus section are an added supplement not mentioned in the original catalog, and also hinges on the fact that the compilers of the Tōhoku catalog placed another text—which forms a whole, very large volume—the Vimalaprabhā­nāmakālacakra­tantraṭīkā (dus ’khor ’grel bshad dri med ’od, Toh 845), before the present volume, numbering it as vol. 100, although it is almost certainly intended to come right at the end of the Degé Kangyur texts as volume 102; indeed its final fifth chapter is often carried over and wrapped in the same volume as the Kangyur dkar chags (catalog). Please note this discrepancy when using the eKangyur viewer in this translation. and Toh 1777, respectively) with additional reference to the notes from the Comparative Editions (dpe sdur ma) of the Kangyur and Tengyur. While the two recensions are largely identical, the Kangyur recension appears to have suffered from some textual corruption during its transmission, which the textually superior Tengyur version fortunately helps to resolve. We have therefore generally given preference to the readings from the recension preserved in the Tengyur, although there were also some instances where the Kangyur recension had the better reading. All instances where the two recensions differed significantly (i.e., in a way that affected the meaning of the text, and therefore the translation) have been noted in the endnotes to the translation.

div.head: The Translation
Praising the Lady Who Rules Disease

div.p: Homage to Glorious Vajrapāṇi. This verse of homage is found only in the Tengyur recension of the text (Toh 1777) and is absent in the Kangyur recension (Toh 1090).

lg.l: O goddess, you wander in this world naked, riding a donkey,
Your hair a single plait anointed with sesame oil.
Seductive and adorned with every ornament,
You wear lead earrings in your ears,
Your feet decorated with iron shackles as anklets.

Understanding your We have emended lha mo khyod nyid kyis to lha mo khyod nyid kyi. beautiful nature may allow others to see you, Following Toh 1777 bdag nyid mdzes par shes kyis gzhan ltas, rather than Toh 1090 bdag nyid mdzes par shes kyi gzhan lta.
But who could understand all the benefits
Of the great ocean of your activity? |1|
When saṃsāra is demolished, when from human bodies Following Toh 1777 mi lus (“human bodies”), rather than Toh 1090 mi rus (“human bones”).
Blood and fat ooze out, and smoke issues forth,
In a single instant, O goddess, you will toss
All beings into your terrifying, fanged mouth.
Black, holding a human skull, delighted by cremation grounds,
You are what yogins seek to accomplish. Following Toh 1090 rnal ’byor grub pa’i spyod yul can, rather than Toh 1777 rnal ’byor grub pa’i rnal ’byor can.
As you ring your terrifying bell, you subdue all that moves,

And clear and pacify Following Toh 1090 ’jigs sel zhi la and the Peking and Narthang recensions of Toh 1777 ’jigs pa gsal zhing zhi la—both lending the meaning “clear fears and pacify”—rather than the Degé edition of Toh 1777 ’jigs pa bsal zhing (“clear fears and”). the fear of illness and death. Following Toh 1090 nad dang ’chi ba (“illness and death”), rather than Toh 1777 nad chen ’chi ba (“the great illness that is death”). |2|
Adorned with a crown made from the heads of heroes,
And a garland of heads severed on the battlefield,
You dance with your delicate arms opened wide,
Wearing the nāga king as a girdle across your broad hips.
Intoxicated by the liquor of blood,
In your hands you brandish a spear and sword.
Your eyes bloodshot, you are seen by the host of bhūtas
Who wander cremation grounds at night. |3|
Wrapped in a large, fresh hide, you wear it

Half-open, Following Toh 1090 ko rlon sar pas dril te brgyang ba’i gos kyis snam phyi phyed g.yogs. Toh 1077 reads ko rlon chen po dral te brgyangs pa’i gos kyis mnabs shing phyed g.yogs. bound with a belt of braided straw.
Your moon-like face is adorned with the hollow tubes
Of fresh human entrails,
And you ring Following Toh 1777 ’khrol (“play”), rather than Toh 1090’dril (“wield”). a bell at your cheek.
Your body freshly oiled and painted with drops

Of mixed blood and fat, Following Toh 1777 khrag dang zhag la sogs pa’i thig les (“drops of blood and fat and the rest”), rather than Toh 1090 khrag dang zhag mang ’dzag pa’i thig les (“many drops of blood and fat that have dropped down”). you carry a skull as you tear

At human flesh Following Toh 1777 mi yi sha (“human flesh”), rather than Toh 1090 mi ro’i sha (“human corpse flesh”) The sense, of course, is essentially the same. with your glistening teeth. Protect me! |4|
Fiercest among fierce ladies, Following Toh 1090 drag po’i drag mo (“fiercest of the fierce ladies”), rather than Toh 1777 drag po drag mo (“fierce males and fierce females”).
Terrifying, with human flesh in your mouth,
The first time they saw you even the mātṛkās were terrified
As you flew into a rage,
Your eyes flickering about—I bow to you!
Kālī, your beautiful black body is so irresistible
That even Śākra and the rest are compelled to praise you daily,
And Yama himself must always bow trembling before you. |5|

You bring an end Following Toh 1777 mjug brtul ba ([you] “bring to an end”) rather than Toh 1090 mjug brtul bas (“because [you] bring to an end”). to humans and all living beings. The first line in this verse in Toh 1090 is two syllables longer that the other three lines in the verse. However, in Toh 1777 the two “extra” syllables are present in all four lines, suggesting Toh 1090 may have lost the extra syllables due to textual corruption over the course of the text’s transmission. In any case, Toh 1777 preserves several preferable readings for this verse.
By one of your ears is a snake

Whose thousand-headed hood adorns you from behind, This line in Toh 1090, brang gis ’gro ba’i mgo bos gdengs ka stong dang ldan pa khyab gnas rgyan tu byas, has multiple textual problems, particularly the phrase khyab gnas, the problematic third-case particle in mgo bos, and the lack of two metrical syllables, so we have followed the reading in Toh 1077: brang gis ’gro ba ’go bo’i gdengs ka stong dang ldan pa rgyab nas rgyan du byas nas gnas, with the minor modification of ’go bo’i to mgo bo’i, with reference to Toh 1090’s reading of this one word, “head.”
And by the other, you hold a peerless lion.
You trample the entire Following Toh 1777 ma lus, omitted in Toh 1090. ocean-encircled earth.
The sun that moves above,
Brilliant with a thousand rays,

Rests directly at your navel. Following Toh 1777 khyod kyi lte ba’i thad ka’i phyogs su gzhags, rather than Toh 1090’s khyod kyis lte ba’i phyogs so bzhag, which omits thad ka, “directly,” and also includes the confusing third case particle kyis, where Toh 1777 has a much better reading with the genitive particle kyi. |6|
You blaze forth from the submarine fire,
Able to dry up the whole of the sea.
Since he can pacify all women,

You are present as half of Mahādeva’s body. This appears to be a reference to Mahākālī as the female half of the half-male half-female form of Śiva called Ardhanārīśvara, the “Lord Who Is Half Female.” Mahādeva is a very common epithet of Śiva. His other half in Ardhanārīśvara form is usually identified as his consort Pārvatī, one of whose common epithets is Gaurī. Indeed the half-half form is sometimes called Ardhagaurīśvara or even simply Gaurīśvara. In the following verse Vararuci identifies Mahākālī with Gaurī—an interesting identification since Gaurī means “Fair One,” whereas Kālī means “Black One.” The statement about Mahādeva/Śiva as one who “can pacify all women” is likely a reference to Śiva’s lying supine on the battlefield or appearing as a child on the battlefield in order to calm Kālī to prevent her from destroying the world. |7|
Durgā, Gaurī, Mahākālī,
To whom gods and asuras pay homage,
You know all human diseases—
Free us from this fear!
Yama’s Queen, Mother of Māra,

Sovereign Goddess of the Desire Realm—I praise you! Following Toh 1777 ’dod khams dbang phyug ma la bstod, which indicates a clear end to the composition, rather than Toh 1090’dod pa’i khams kyi dbang phyug ma, which somewhat confusingly blends the verse into the author’s colophon. |8|

div.trailer: This concludes “Praising the Lady Who Rules Disease”, composed by the Brahmin Vararuci.

gloss.term: The point of origin for the fire that consumes the universe at the end of an eon.
Sovereign Goddess of the Desire Realm

A common epithet of Indra, the lord of the gods, who dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation is based on an etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu: one who has performed a hundred sacrifices (Tib. brgya byin). The highest Vedic sacrifice was the horse sacrifice, and there is a tradition that he became the lord of the gods through performing a hundred of them.
Īśvara (dbang phyug) “Mighty One” is one of the most frequently used names for Śiva.
A goddess, an epithet of Śiva’s consort Pārvatī.
